title: How many of the BRIC countries will report positive annualised growth for the quarter ending in December 2015?
preds: Essentially this becomes a question of whether Russia will post positive results since the other 3 are rather certain. While its extremely unlikely they have actual positive growth, there is some chance that they will be close enough that fudging of numbers of true errors in initial reporting of the numbers.
I doubt Brazil or Russia will grow.
The International Monetary Fund predicted that the emerging market economies will be even weaker next year!
Not going so well for them.
Brazil & Russian taking political, commodity & currency hits while China although growing more slowly continues to outpace along India's economy which just might surprise for 2016 to the upside.

China and India are the only ones with positive GDPs in 2015.
However, a rising U.S. dollar could hurt all of the BRICS countries next year.
Russian Nov GDP shows a contraction - Oct/Nov contraction is almost 4% so OND is certain to contract vs YA. Therefore, only 2 countries (China & India) will register growth in OND.
India and China are growing.  Brazil is not.  Russia is the only question mark, but I don't think it will print growth.
China will not go negative.  Russia and Russia can not be positive - both are too tied to oil.  The only questionable one is India.
Updating for passage of time and by http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-12-30/the-world-economy-s-winners-and-losers-in-2015

Some help for the BRIC forecasters, from the following: http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-12-30/the-world-economy-s-winners-and-losers-in-2015 "In the emerging market world, clear standouts included Vietnam, Tanzania and, wait for it, China. Even after a $5 trillion stock market rout and what's tipped to be the slowest growth in 25 years, China's overall gross domestic product growth remains relatively robust compared to its peers. India's economy also expanded faster than expected in the third quarter when GDP rose 7.4 percent from a year earlier, after a 7 percent expansion in the previous quarter.   The weakest performers included the usual suspects. Russia is on track for its longest slump in two decades mostly because of lower oil prices. Brazil has been dogged by the commodities slump, political turmoil, a corruption scandal and a widening budget gap. Goldman Sachs Group Inc. warned that the nation is sinking into “an outright depression.""
Maintaining my forecast as is due to passage of time and no convincing data suggesting that a number different than 2 (India and China) will report positive annualized growth.
Data has been clear for quite some time. However, one should never rule out revisions in growth rates if at any point in the very distant future, growth is calculated under different parameters

China and India both registering a negative GDP print is ~ 0% probability since 2015 is almost over and we know there has been no massive global crisis. The question boils down to the predictions for Russia and Brazil (both of which registered -ve prints for the first 3 quarters of 2015).
Russia: After the revision of Q3 GDP to -4.1% for Russia chances of a rebound above 0 is very low (since oil has remained flat with a decline in dec). 
Brazil: Professional forecasters recently decreased their forecast for 2016 from -2.8% to -2.81%. This is dismal for Q4 2015 too.
I am more confident that India will show positive growth.China should come in with something less than 7%....but still growth over prior year.
Brazil may not, for the rest growth will be low but postive

http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/business/2015-12/28/content_22838801.htm The Swiss banking group expected Q4 growth of 6.9 percent year on year, bringing 2015 growth to between 6.9 percent and 7 percent.

Very unlikely Russia or Brazil will grow. The latest from Russia puts a wet blanket on the bits of positive news from October. 
http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-12-28/russian-gdp-shrinks-first-time-since-june-as-longer-slump-looms
http://www.cnbc.com/2015/12/28/too-early-for-optimism-on-russia-growth-analyst.html
Russia has almost no chance of positive growth. Brazil has lots of problems but might manage positive growth. But China and India are nearly guaranteed to show positive growth.
Going for the only realistic (Real GDP) option

Providing a brief update. Brazil and Russia are in recession as previously mentioned and there has been no suggestion of a reversal. Given their reliance on commodities, oil in particular, does not bode well for a reversal in this trend. I am very confident that both will post a negative figure. China's growth has slowed but it is not negative. Nowhere near it in Q3. For two reasons, I find negative growth near impossible. 1) Growth was well above zero for the entirety of the year and there have not been enough changes to suggest a sudden change 2) The figures are arguably not accurate. I don't see why the government would choose to share a negative number. India's growth has also slowed and they have experienced some issues with the auto industry, etc. but for the most part the economy still suggests that GDP is very positive. I see no compelling reason for growth to be negative. The only material change is that I see virtually no chance of 3 countries posting positive GDP growth but there is an outside shot that India would be negative (very outside). For the most part, my thesis has not changed in that I see it most likely that India and China will display positive growth.

Russian economics ministry says they're down 4% in November and 3.7% in October. Nobody's December is good enough to make up for those numbers. (Still a smallish chance that the ministry will be provided with guidance from Putin to fix it, I suppose, but that would require a pretty big fix.) Brazil is still a basket case, and the other two are still on track for a quarter that's at least up, even if not by as much as they'd like.  http://www.reuters.com/article/us-russia-economy-gdp-idUSKBN0UB0EV20151228
Russia is a no, China and India are a yes. Question is Brazil.
India and China are unlikely to enter recession.

BRIC nations have no origin of inventions, apart from Russia rest of the nations are just copy cat nations so then need some one in front of them to copy cat and then feed the economy so the cycle cant move the other way around,.
economy growth depends on quality of the nation and its rulers motive! so positive growth will be a challenge.
India and China are still growing albeit much more slowly
Certainly China will and Russia and Brazil will not. The question is will India or not
Their economies are the only growing.
Editing just to comment that the question says "report."

Exports for BRIC countries are weak due to low commodity prices.  Brazil, Russia, are dependent on exports.
India looks better due to its politics.  China is unpredictable due to dishonest politicians releasing information.
Both Russia and Brazil have registered negative growth rates this year.

Brazil's economy is in ruins due to poor fiscal spending and competitiveness issues. Russia is a mess from falling oil prices and sanctions. India will show positive grow. China will report positive growth.

India and China will definitely report a positive growth. Brazil and Russia reported negative numbers last quarters and there is nothing to suggest of any turnaround. Factored a small % for Russia fudging numbers or generating growth due to energy exports in winter months.

China has been making positive growth this year so I set 0 at 0%. 
Brazil has been making negative growth this year so I set 4 at 0%.
Russia has been on the negative side due to the oil slump and western sanctions, so very likely to be contracting in Q415.
That leaves China and India on the positive territory.

Regardless of actual growth BRIC will look to report growth for political reasons.
-India has a strong case to report annualized growth (independent forecasts put it at 7-8%)
-China is likely to have suffered a year on year slow down but the central statistics bureau may report higher growth.
-Russia will report growth for domestic political reasons regardless of its downturn
-Brazil is the least likely to be able to fudge figures but may be able to utilize infrastructure investment to boost its figures
China & India have reported positive & will report Q4 positive annualized growth. Brazil certain to record another negative quarter. Some chance of Russia reporting a positive growth for Q4.

Brazil and Russia ; No, India and China Yes.
Brazil will announce a .8 shrinkage the real number is 3x that.
Russia will announce small increase which is a lie.
India will be above 7 annualized and they will REALLy do near that.
China will announce 1.75, the real number will be 1.25
Russia and Brazil's economic woes and political problems show no significant signs of abating, but compared to the disastrous Q4 last year Russia could still improve
India is the only 1 that has a well documented year. China could lie and say numbers are up when all other indicators say they are down

Based upon the wording of the headline question, it seems to refer to a positive growth for the 4th quarter alone.   Note that quarterly GDP is always based on the change in GDP from the prior quarter (i.e. Q3).  "Annualized" means you take a quarterly figure and annualize it (1+ r/100)^4.  However, reading the question description, it seems to refer to annual (not annualized) growth (i.e. ending GDPQ4'15/ending GDPQ4'14 - 1) or year over year growth.  
If that is what is desired, a much clearer way to phrase the question would be how many of the countries would show positive YoY real GDP growth at the end of Q4 2015 or even more simply, show positive GDP growth for the full year 2015.   There is almost no way for either Brazil or Russia to have positive GDP growth for the full year 2015.

Brazil and Russia continue to suffer from low commodity prices and political actors who either cannot or will not make the structural and political changes necessary to improve growth. But it is possible Russia posts modestly positive growth in Q4, but unlikely. It's more likely they surprise to the upside in 2016 if at all.
Correction. I was including South Africa to the mix. The question says BRIC, not BRICS

Only India and China will show positive annualized growth in Dec 2015. Both Brazil and Russia are stuck in recessions, the former due to the commodities bust and corruption allegations against the ruling party affecting public investments and crippling growth and the latter due to the collapse in natural gas prices as well as continued implementation of sanctions by the United States and the European Union.
India and China are still growing; Brazil and Russia are not.

http://www.worldbank.org/en/news/press-release/2014/12/08/world-bank-revises-its-growth-projections-for-russia-for-2015-and-2016
http://pubdocs.worldbank.org/pubdocs/publicdoc/2015/12/676661449848465292/Russia-Monthly-Economic-Developments-December-2015-eng.pdf As per the work bank they have forecasted at best a 0% decline in GDP for Q4, Moodys bas increased there bond rating. FY14 they already declined to .6% growth and have reported negative for 3 quarters, gas is under $40 a barrel and they need $74 per barrel to balance the budget as per the world bank. Some have mentioned that they may "cook the books" however, with international pressure this is unlikely, as international and even local investors would likely leave divest interest in the case of blatant fraudulent reporting. Further destabilizing the economy.   http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/cde3085a-a816-11e5-843e-626928909745.html Brazil has had continued economic crisis, 0 percent chance of positive annualized growth.

Brazil is looking more likely to post negative growth this quarter, as they just replaced their finance minister. Odds of Brazil posting negative rise to about 80 percent. Oil prices remain low, but if Russia begins to stagnate GDP won't drop significantly from the last quarter, odds of decreasing again about 70 percent.

Growth in China has slowed down and Modi's policies will take time to accelerate growth in India. Solow growth model suggests that they will keep growing albeit with erratically, until they are at par with the developed economies. Same logic applies to Brazil and Russia but they face dire short-term risks. Brazil's commodity exports have collapsed and her finances with it. Russia's oil and gas revenues have collapsed, military expenditures have gone up. Current account and fiscal balances adjust slowly. Besides, they face corruption scandals and sanctions as the cherry on top. However, there is some chance that one of them (probably Russia) posts mildly positive growth. First, reporting is a bit muddy; they can report positive as an national accounting wonder. Second, military expenditures have stimulus effect, possibly large in Russia's case where the economy is tethering. Finally, oil and gas prices have declined but we don't know much about the volume of contracts state-owned oil and gas companies signed.

Brazil by all estimates continued continued to crater, economically, now politically with impeachment.Oil prices did  not go in this quarter and Brazil is not pumping  $75-billion invested in  deep water salt domes and no oil production due to ongoing criminal prosecutions of the leaders of politic, business magnates,  so this process is acceleratig thru this quarter.
Russia
1. Oil prices
2, Sanctions
3. Corruption
QED contraction this quarter.
Hey lets hope the New year bring some solutions to numerous potentially existential  theatsl, vel non  Global Warming.
This tournament and the materials make projections more than 5 years out seem very risky.

.I believe China has a high probability  of having positive yo y growth,albeit smaller than the last few years growth.India could have positive growth in the 4th quarter if the past quarterly trends continue

Brazil has been in economic decline due to prolonged social issues (corruption, etc). Russia will also likely have trouble due to extrinsic factors (sanctions, etc). India is performing well and should have positive growth. China will also experience positive growth, albeit at a slower rate than previous years.

http://www.econotimes.com/China-GDP-growth-likely-to-be-at-60-in-2016-134765#wIU0zixiIkied3Ci.99 re:  China: "We maintain our 2016 GDP growth forecast of 6.0% amid continued headwinds from capacity unwinding and destocking, with weaker growth in Q4 2015 expected (2015: 6.8%) ", estimates Barclays.
~~~~~~~
COMMENT:  With most sources showing China's Q4 2014 annualized real GDP growth as 7.4%, this forecast suggests that relative to Q4 2015, China will not show positive annualized real GDP growth . . . if I understand this question correctly.

BRICs were oversold in the run up to the financial crisis. Since then they have been sustained by China's growth and quantitive easing in the 1st world. Now the tide is receding with China's slowdown and commodity price falls the structural imbalances, fiscal weakness and political deficit in the BRICs has come to the fore with predictable results
Brazil and Russia are going to continue in their path of recession

India & China certainly will
Russia & Brazil are currently between 0-1% and could slip below, however, they are both and lows and could bounce back a little for positive annualized growth for the year

Since this is going to close in 9 days, and economists are still predicting negative Q4 annualized GDP growth in the -0.8 through -2 range for Brazil (and worse for Russia), I'm going all in, Brazil and Russia will be negative. India and China are easy positives.
India has best chance, oil is down so Russia struggles, Olympics in Brazil are draining the country dry, China has just slowed too much
Among the BRICS only India is doing good. China might be able to keep up its growth but that is unlikely.
FED pushing interest rates up and weak performance/growth through the year

all reached the bottom peak of recession 
russia and brazil may be a little  below zero

India and China both have seen growth for several years, albeit China's is slowing. They are unlikely to see a fall in their GDP. Brazil and Russia are in serious recessions, the former will only be able to return to growth once government policies are changed and then take effect - and could do with commodity prices taking a turn for the better, which is unlikely in the near future given a slowdown in demand and strong supply almost across the board. Russia might possibly benefit from some kind of oil shock.

Long shot given further erosion of oil prices and sanctions, but there appear to be some signs that the Russian economy has begun to stabilize (age manufacturing). See http://www.focus-economics.com/countries/russia: "economic recession in Russia hit rock bottom in mid-2015. A preliminary estimate shows that GDP decreased 4.1% in Q3 over the same quarter last year, which is up from the 4.6% contraction observed in Q2 when the economy experienced the worst contraction in six years. Lower oil prices, a decline in real wages, the weakening of the ruble and the impact from external economic factors continued to weigh on the Russian economy in Q3. However, initial signs of stabilization are coming from the industrial sector, while performance in the agricultural sector is also looking better." Therefore increasing odds of 3 from 0% to 2% (1 in 50),
China will claim a positive number regardless. India will actually be positive. Russia and Brazil are both suffering from falling commodity prices

China and India - definitely
Brazil - no
Russia - unlikely
South Africa - unlikely

India is the only economy that will show positive growth. China is going to cook the numbers as usual. Hence, l would put it in the growth category. Both Russia and Brazil will have no chance of growth.  Oil and war hurts Russia and corruption hurts Brazil.

Recent estimates have China and India clearing positive growth. Russia is expected to stay in recession and the decrease in oil prices likely means they will have negative GDP growth.  Brazil is also expected to have negative GDP growth.  I would give it a 5% chance Brazil rebounds and a 3% chance Russia does.

Brazil and Russia have almost no chance of growing next year. In Brazil high interest rates and low commodity prices combined with high debt levels will strangle the economy.
The only thing that could prevent China growing is a global recession. Ditto India as these economies maintain slowing but still significant growth momentum.

Extreme possibilities looking more remote with recent political turmoil in Brazil and the continued fall in commodity prices which affects both Brazil and Russia substantially. There remains an outside chance that Putin intervenes with the official numbers reported, but it is very likely that Brazil and Russia will decline while China and India will post strong growth numbers.

Russia and Brazil are in negative growth (1.2% - Brazil; 4.1% - Russia) as of the 3rd quarter. Brazil has a combination of factors contributing to continued negative growth: 1. Budget cuts. 2. Rising inflation. 3. Political corruption. Russia's problems with economic growth are similar to Brazil's with commodity prices being the biggest culprit for its negative GDP growth. India and China, despite slow downs, are looking to retain their positive growth numbers with consumer spending on services still increasing.

Brazil no chance
Russia no
India and Russia yes
Chinese growth still there, India OK, Russia and Brazil slowing. Low commodity prices.
Brazil and Russia both in trouble. India and China seem very likely to stay positive even if not as high as predicted.
Adjusting for higher confidence. Original argument stands.  China and India will post growth, and Brazil and Russia will not.
Brazil and Russia dependent on oil export profits. Their GDP YoY is currently negative and very unlikely to have improved in the last quarter.

India last reported negative growth 35 years ago. India has seen improving numbers due to positive political reforms and favourable demographics. Likelihood of reporting positive annualised growth: 99%.
China began reporting GDP growth in 1990 and hasn't yet reported negative growth. While GDP growth has slowed it is still a healthy 7%. Even if it would spectacularly crash, it is unlikely that Chinese authorities would admit to negative growth. Likelihood of reporting positive annualised growth: 99%.
Brazil has seen GDP growth turn negative and fundamentals have only deteriorated of late. Credit ratings are being downgraded, political uncertainty and the crash in commodity prices make a positive number very unlikely. Likelihood of reporting positive annualised growth: 10%.
Russia too has suffered for many similar reasons to Brazil and is also very likely to report negative growth. However there is a risk that government intervenes to prevent having to admit such awful numbers. Likelihood of reporting positive annualised growth: 20%.
Brazil & Russia in recession. India & China, not.
India and China is the only once that makes it

What happened to Africa's "most industrialized" nation, South Africa. Aren't they part of the BRICS group?  It seems that the BRIC group you mention have all been engaged in a lot of "creative" accounting procedures. Analysts and experts can predict all they want but actual data is guarded by sovereign interests. The implications being, unless leaked, industrial-economic espionage.
China maintains growth, even if at a lower rate. India too is a growth economy . The others not under current circumstances

Brazil seems most likely to report negative growth, but it has already reported several quarters of negative growth (more than any time since the early 1990s). Recessions (defined by negative growth) don't tend to last very long. I think Brazil has a 62 percent chance to come out of the recession (even though it may be short lived). This may be high given the political turmoil though. Russia also seems to have hit rock bottom and is growing again. The US/Europe is unlikely to push for more sanctions given the ISIS debacle and oil prices probably aren't going to fall by much more. I think the probability of Russia reporting negative GDP growth is about 19 percent.  China and India are unlikely to report negative GDP growth. I would say their odds are less than 1 percent each. Also, it's already December and nothing drastic has happened in those markets. With prob of Brazil at 62, Russia at 19, China and India both at 1 the probability of all four reporting negative growth is .62*.19*.01*.01 is basically zero. Brazil and China .62*.19 = 12 percent (round up to account for the chance of I or C). Odds of any 3: .99*.99*.81 + .99*.99*.38 +2*(.38*.81+.99) = 82 and all 4: 99*.99*.81*.38=30.  These all add up to 124, downweight by

Upping two to 100% (from 98%). See initial forecast --> https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/59392 I see nothing that indicates that India/China will have negative Q4's and nothing that indicates Brazil/Russia will have positive Q4's. QED.

December 10, 2015—".  . . . . Medvedev claimed Russia’s economy was no longer receding and, by his estimation, would begin growing in 2016. Russian economists, however, described Medvedev’s assessment as having little grasp of economic reality and being overly optimistic in forecasting growth. “All the authorities in Russia have raised their voices and said that the GDP (gross domestic product) will still be shrinking,” said Andrei Movchan, director of the Economic Policy Program at the Carnegie Moscow Center.  “The Ministry of Finance was talking about -1.5 percent; the Central Bank was talking about -1.5 percent, at least; a few other personalities and authorities were talking about even worse figures, like -2, -2.5 percent.” "The Russian prime minister acknowledged that other authorities disagreed with him, including Russia’s Central Bank, which projects no growth until 2017.  But he still tried to paint a more positive outlook, saying “under the most pessimistic forecasts we’ll have zero growth.”  
. . . .
"Russia’s economy is suffering as a result of its dependence on raw material exports like oil, with oil prices at their lowest point in seven years, as well as Western sanctions over the Kremlin’s actions in Ukraine. "There has been a slight reduction in how quickly Russia’s economy has been contracting, but it is still expected to shrink by at least 4 percent this year.
. . . 
"Igor Nikolayev, director of strategic analysis at the Moscow-based audit consulting company FBK, disputes Medvedev's claim.  “I see that the anti-crisis plan has not worked, the economy continues to be in crisis and, in reality, we won't have economic growth next year,” he told VOA. “No 1.7 percent growth envisaged next year, but a decline by probably 2-3 percent.”
. . . .“The most important peculiarity of the present crisis that Russia is living through is that without the fall in oil prices, and without the sanctions, the Russian economy would have gotten into a crisis anyway, because serious structural disproportions and structural problems have accumulated,” Nikolayev said. "The prime minister acknowledged that oil still accounts for 44 percent of Russia’s federal budget, but said its importance is changing.  “Oil used to account for 50, 60 and even 70 percent of the budget revenue,” Medvedev said.  “This goes to say that our budget revenue structure is changing for the better.”
.  . . .
"Despite concerns that consumer prices, already up thanks to Russian counter-sanctions targeting Western food imports, may continue to rise, Medvedev defended a ban on Turkish fruits and vegetables set to go into effect in January. “I’m not going to contest the fact that counter-sanctions affect prices to a certain extent. But this impact is not fatal,” he said.  “We have started to forget that food price inflation in early 2008 was 13 percent, you can look it up. And in early 2015 it remained at a similar level.” "The sanctions were announced after a Turkish jet shot down a Russian warplane along its border with Syria for allegedly crossing into Turkish airspace despite repeated warnings.  Russia denies the Su-24 crossed the border and called the action a planned provocation.   "Medvedev said Russia could have justifiably gone to war with Turkey:  “How did states normally behave in a situation like this in the 20th century? A war started, because this amounts to a direct attack on a foreign state.”   "The prime minister added: “Naturally, in our present life, under current circumstances, a war is the worst option.”
~~~~~~~
COMMENT:  How's Russia doing, economically?  Not great and not improving.  It's so bad that the weak state of the economy is impacting foreign policy!  So, anyway you slice and dice what "positive annualized growth in real GDP in Q4 2015" is, Russia is a "no". I'm changing my forecast to what I believe is correct.  It's just not in my DNA to just follow the crowd.

I have been unable to submit my prediction for weeks but it finally works! I'll add a summary of the analysis I did a while back: I first started by looking at the GDP growth for Q3 for these countries and then assessed what the trends were caused by. Brazil - declining oil prices and metal. sustained commodity woes and corruption suggest that this trend continues
Russia - significant reliance on oil. given the recent (further) slides in oil prices, I forecast with high confidence that this trend continues in Q4.
India - posted strong, positive growth and I find no compelling reason that this trend will reverse.
China - despite commodity pressure and declining growth, I am very confident that they will still post relatively strong single-digit growth (I am defining strong as well above 0, i.e. 3% or higher). I believe their published GDP may be overstated for this quarter so may not be accurate however given this trend, I see no reason that growth will turn negative. Given the strong commodity reliance of Russia and Brazil, I am fairly certain that they will post negative GDP. China and India's cases on the other hand suggest a strong chance of positive growth. I am almost certain of 2 countries posting positive GDP in Q4.

growth is the natural trajectory of all human societies, even though decline gets all the headlines.  That being said, the headwinds are that at least 1 of these countries will have a recession, so all 4 growing seems unlikely.  Giving three the most weight.
China and India are dead certs. Brazil and Russia could each sneak a positive figure, with negative growth now factored in

China will REPORT positive growth.  People arent really sure about reality, but China almost definitely will report positive.
India positive.
Brasil clearly negative and commodity prices continue to fall.
Russia depends a lot on oil.  Oil price is down.  Natty plans scuttled lately in Ukraine.  http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-11-25/russia-halts-natural-gas-supplies-to-ukraine-as-prepayments-end.  So pretty hard to go from down 4% annualized to positive in 1 quarter.

China and India both clearly positive growth for the year. China's growth rate is slowing but it is still growing at over 6%
Brazil clearly negative.
Russia may grow in the last quarter, but not year over year (i.e. annualized).
So changing to 100% for two countries, and 0 for all other choices.
China and India will certainly grow. Russia and Brazil will not

Real GDP Growth India and China
Nominal GDP basis Russia may also deliver positive growth

From the data & projections I can find
A)    1 country (India) will have a Q4 real GDP growth rate that is positive and higher than the previous year.
B)    2 countries (India & China) will have Q4 real GDP growth rates that are positive. I think statement A is the answer to the question, given the definition of "positive annualized real GDP growth rate" in More Info. Most other forecasters seem to think that the statement B answers the question. I disagree, but I give up.

Knock me over with a feather! I've been trying to submit a forecast since December 8, but there was a bug in the page. My forecast finally went through! Hoping I don't regret it. None of the BRIC countries are borderline. Two firmly in positive territory and two firmly in negative territory in year-over-year growth. The numbers: https://stats.oecd.org/index.aspx?queryid=350
China is beginning to get a bumpy ride.
China and India are shoe-in. Russia is shoe-out, if I may say so. Brazil prospects appear to worsen.

I gave 4 PhDs in Econ this question and the sentence from "More Info", then asked them what a "positive annualized GDP growth rate" is.  Their answers were: #1 said:  "It's complicated.  I don't have the time to explain it."
#2 said:  an answer I don't understand because it involves math I can't do. 
#3 said: a positive GDP OR improved GDP growth rate over the previous year.
#4 said:  a positive GDP AND improved GDP growth rate  over the previous year Today, I classify the 4 countries as follows as having economies that are . . .   with annualized GDP growth rates that are . . . . : Brazil: worsening, negative 
Russia:  worsening, negative
India:  improving, positive
China:  worsening, positive Here's 4 different interpretations of the question and how I'd forecast for each today: A)  If it means economies with a positive annualised GDP, my forecast today would be:
100% for 2  (india, China).  
Initially, this is how I interpreted the question. I thought then that maybe Russia might report a positive GDP, so I forecast 85% for 2, 15% for 3.  B)  If it means economies that are improving, my forecast today would be:
100% for 1  (India)  
This is the interpretation I was going by when I changed my forecast and I thought that Russia's GDP might be improving and wasn't sure how India was doing, so I forecast 25% for none, 75% for 1. C)  It it means economies that are improving OR positive, my forecast today would be:
100% for 2  (India, China) D)  If it means economies that are improving AND positive, my forecast today would be:
100% for 1 (India) I'm going to go with interpretation B because it is the only one that meets the criteria of  "positive in comparison". And I'm going to go all the way because I think I'm right, there's a 50% chance that the answer "1" is right, and I'm not in the mood to play games. Post mortem: Thinking you know something is far more hazardous than knowing you don't, because in the first instance you don't even know that there's anything that needs to be remedied.    I thought I knew what the question was asking for before I made my first forecast; now, I realize that I did not/do not, and I regret ever having participated.
Russia no, Brazil unlikely, India yes
possible India, minor china, Russia and Brazil no chance due to oil price

Putin says they've hit bottom and things will start to get better.  This is of course not true, but might provide an incentive for his gummint to falsify Q4 numbers.  (Not many people are surprised when the current Russian government massages facts.)
The over/under is zero, pretty low bar. Commodities have not recovered hurting both Russia and Brazil. Nominal GDP may be positive in 3 but real should be positive in only india and china.
Lower oil prices may affect a couple of countries.
http://www.examiner.com/article/brazilians-protest-against-president-dilma-rousseff-and-government-corruption Brazil:  Q3 GDP down 4.5 percent YoY
My answer for all 4 is zero. Russia will probably falter.
US will raise interest rates, which will lead to a flow of capital from BRIC to the dollar.
I have pretty high conviction that Brazil and Russia will continue to decline, equally India and China are both doing quite well and have a lot of headroom before any slowing becomes negative.

No way China or India will post negative q/q growth. Things obviously looking less sanguine in Russia and Brazil, with fairly low chances of either showing positive growth. Note that q/q growth rates are quite hard to forecast and this should be accounted for in terms of the projections.

India is experiencing strong growth. All officials statistics also suggest China is still growing.
The resource countries Russia and Brazil are both is deep recessions. 2/4

India and China almost certainly will. Russia is highly likely not to (-4.1% GDP in Q3'15), similar to Brazil (-4.4% in Q3'15). This divergence is significant. The likelihood that either India or China will report a negative number is very close to zero, while the likleihood of a positive number from either of Russia or Brazil is similarly very low. Moreover, we are almost at the end of Q4 already. It is almost inconceivable at this point for somethign so dramatically negative to happen in China and India as to drag the average Q4 growth rate to negative - even earthquakes of significant proportions, wars and terrorism all combined might not take the overall growth rate to negative given that the majority of the quarter now has already been positive. The same is true in terms of a positive event of similar magnitude in Russia or Brazil - even oil going to $200 might not drag up Russia's Q4 GDP to positive levels - even if Q1'16 would then certainly be at that level in this scenario.  I am very confident that the number is 2 positive growth levels in GDP for BRIC countries in Q4'15.

I am going to use the interpretation of the question consistent with the More Info related to the question to create my forecast - that is, that "positive annualised growth for the quarter ending" means comparing GDP in 2015 Q4 against GDP in 2014 Q4 for a nonnegative change. This is consistent with the link from @Rene on Baseline Scenario's "Column G" interpretation. This is my source for data: https://stats.oecd.org/index.aspx?queryid=350 , though I have also looked at government sources myself for Brazil and China. I think that India and China are near 100% for nonnegative growth from 2014 to 2015 Q4's. I think both Brazil and Russia are going to be near 100% likely to be at negative growth from 2014 to 2015 Q4's.

Since this question compares the GDP of Q4 2015 compared to that of Q4 2014, and not Q4 to Q3, a reversal of the trend from Q1-Q3 is not very likely. I found this explanation to be helpful: http://baselinescenario.com/2009/04/30/gdp-growth-rates-for-beginners/ We are asked for the outcome of column G, not column C.

it is almost impossible that Brazil report a positive, it is also hard to believe china will "report" a negative growth. India is growing decently. Here is Russia, the wild card, still the probability of positive GDP considering oil prices and the impact of sanctions is slow.

It would take Black Swan events (low prob by definition) to cause all 4 economies to show negative annualized Q4 growth. Likewise, India and China's economic inertia would make it unlikely that only one economy achieved positive growth in the same period. While it seems unlikely, Russia or Brazil *might* have some low probability of joining China and India with a positive Q4 , it is unlikely. All four being Q4 positive is very unlikely, but never a zero probability. Edit: it would seem I misunderstood the question and possibly should have looked more closely at China's trend, seeing if Q4 2015 looked to exceed Q4 2014. I still think India will be net positive year over year for Q4: China not so sure but not going to put in more homework since the question is closed.

OK. I think I get it now. If I take "the same quarter of the previous year" to be the period in which the measure is taken, rather than the measure of the period, it works. Assuming no Russian surprise. Final note on this: the phrase "slowdowns in growth" is misleading. This implies a change (reduction) in the rate of (positive) change. In truth, the question is asking about a rate of change in activity, not about a change in the rate of change in activity. Apple will, hopefully, experience a slowdown in growth of iPhone units, but not a reduction in units. Finis.

I am having difficulty with this Question because it seems that the following statement from the "More Info" section is contradictory to a more standard interpretation; namely,
"Annualised quarterly growth rates measure the change in real GDP compared to the same quarter of the previous year." According to this definition then, 
Annualized quarterly growth rate = [either] GDP quarter Q (of year X) - GDP quarter Q (of year X-1) [or] Δ GDP quarter Q (of year X) - Δ GDP quarter Q (of year X-1) But this is not correct. The standard interpretation of Annualized Quarterly Growth Rate is: [1, 2]
(GDP current quarter year X/ GDP previous quarter year X)^4 - 1 Thus, annualized quarterly growth rates measure the change in real GDP between consecutive quarters, adjusted to a comparable scale. [1] https://books.google.com/books?id=l1iHhX9ed9kC&pg=PA26&lpg=PA26&dq=%22annualized+quarterly+growth+rate%22&source=bl&ots=a3Z8KkG2-A&sig=eqysvjSO-RG0n9vILLh3_y2Edn4&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi_7Jmg1tLJAhUDPj4KHfUiAUsQ6AEISTAJ#v=onepage&q=%22annualized%20quarterly%20growth%20rate%22&f=false
[2] https://books.google.com/books?id=s-VLkDNeqxwC&pg=PT32&lpg=PT32&dq=%22Annualized+quarterly+growth+rate%22+formula&source=bl&ots=MpeweRbogb&sig=wBamYs1nwgdC1WzSmJh6fqxpgjo&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwitgMHM4NLJAhUFbD4KHd51DCgQ6AEILTAE#v=onepage&q=%22Annualized%20quarterly%20growth%20rate%22%20formula&f=false I note that the group has overwhelmingly disregarded the definition of Annualized Quarterly Growth Rate as presented in the "More Info" section. To do this, one must correct this proffered definition to read something more like:
"Annualized quarterly growth rates measure the change in real GDP between consecutive quarters, adjusted to allow comparison with the same quarter of the previous year (or any other quarter for that matter)." I apologize, but the references to "change" and "the same quarter of the previous year" in the proffered definition are really throwing me off. Typically, one wants to make the argument of another "work," but I guess in this case when the definition is so wrong, and we have no opportunity to clarify, we must abandon the proffered definition. [It is curious that the group is so willing to abandon the source definition of "what is" in this instance, and yet is so reluctant to do so with the OPEC quota.]

India has been positive for 3 quarters (ie = yes)
Russia has been negative for 3 quarters, so their fourth quarter would have to be monster positive to overcome that (ie = no)
Brazil has been negative for 3 quarters (6 actually) so similarly their fourth quarter would have to be monster too (1.e. = no) Caveat, if this is a comparison between 4th quarter 2014 growth rate versus fourth quarter 2015 growth rate (like I originally thought), then I go back to my original prediction of one. and will have a bourbon that night to make things better.

http://www.statista.com/statistics/271769/quarterly-gross-domestic-product-gdp-growth-rate-in-china/ Ok now let's take a first stab at the question:  Let's assign a 99% chance that India (projected 1.8%*4in the links above) and China (projected 1.3%*4) will see growth. Considering the history of these two countries the near 100% guess is probably safe.  Looking at the forecasts from the links above for Brazil (-1% * 4) and Russia (-1%*4), it's probably safe to assign high probability to the outcome that they'll shrink. Since the forecast was identical, let's assign a probability p for brazil shrinking and also p for russia shrinking.  Now: Probability of answer (2) = p^2 
Probability of answer (3) = p*(1-p)*2
Probability of answer (4) = (1-p)^2 Now the (relatively ?) hard part is picking p. I took p = .95 (and artificially boosted (4)).

Clear recession in Brazil and Russia and Growth in India and China for 2015. Brazil: Negative. Base Case: Expected 2015 annual shrink on GDP at 3% in 2015. Downside: Rising unemployment rate, increasing Bond yield reflects risk premium, Political crisis with impeachment request against President
Russia: Negative. Base Case: Expected 2015 annual shrink on GDP at 3.7% in 2015. Downside: Continuous lower bound on commodity prices
India: Positive. Base Case: Expected 2015 annual shrink on GDP at 7.1% in 2015. Upside: Best market within BRIC and surpassed expectiation in Q3, Ongoing pickup in Indian output. Though new GDP calculation methodology makes comparison difficult
China: Positive. Base Case: Expected 2015 annual shrink on GDP at 6.9% in 2015. No significant contraction seen in Q4, with China's central bank easing to support growth. Downside: Weak demand on China's steel industry with potential debt crisis risk, minimal impact in GDP within this short period of tim.

I'm going to roll some dice and say China can't surpass last year's annualised growth.

Russia - We've already seen oil prices plunge further to below $40/bbl for Brent, and as oil prices plunge, so will Russia's GDP. Putin's hesitant tone is unusual, and leads me to believe that more bad news is in store.  Brazil - The continued rout in commodity prices will only make things harder for this commodity exporting economy. Steel, iron, and copper prices continue to come under stress. Oil prices keep tumbling, further crushing Petrobras under its pile of debt. Uncertainty surrounding the impeachment of Rousseff will reduce investment in the country across the board.  China - China's published growth numbers are likely a farce, and for that reason, I see no material chance that the government will change its stance and dare to publish a negative figure for the quarter. They also have yet to stop subsidizing their overly indebted commodity producers. There's no reason to believe they'll produce negative growth during Q4.  India - Another bright spot among the BRIC countries. There's no reason to believe they'll plunge from high single digit growth to negative growth during the fourth quarter. Any fears that flooding will result in a soft quarter may be valid, but with Chennai representing a meager ~5 million people, it shouldn't cause the economic drag needed to bring growth rates into negative territory.

I didn't take econ.  So, yesterday I asked a couple of people what a "positive annualized growth rate" is.  I should have just read the "fine print" here!  In "more info" it says: "Annualised quarterly growth rates measure the change in real GDP compared to the same quarter of the previous year." So, I think all of the following would be positive annualised growth rates:
Q4 2014 = -1.2,   Q4 2015 = -1.0  
Q4 2014 =  3.3     Q4 2015 = 4.6 I think that the following would be negative annualised growth rates:
Q4 2014 = -1.2    Q4 2015 = -1.4
Q4 2014 =  6.9    Q4 2015 = 5.7 What I understand, then, is that this question is asking, "In how many of these countries is this year's 4th quarter going to have been better than last year's 4th quarter?"   . . . . How this differs from how I understood that question yesterday is that a country that is experiencing negative growth can still show "positive annualized growth" if this year the decline isn't as bad as it was last year. I think that the following countries are growing slower now than in 2014:
Brazil.  Rousseff is so embattled, she's having a hard time getting through the legislation she needs to fix budget issues, so I imagine this year Q4 will be worse than last year's.
Russia.  I don't know how this year's Q4 could be better than last year Q4 when the price of oil is so much lower this year.
China.  Everything I read is that China is headed downward. So that's 3.  I don't know about India. I need to get a lock on what each country's 2014 Q4 was, and then start looking at projections for this year.

China and India are safe for the immediate future. Of all the developing world India is actually in comparatively robust shape.  Brazil and Russia are in recession from poor economic policies and the commodity cycle. Russia's economy is largely  dependent on hydrocarbons, raw commodities, military tech exports, agriculture, and space launch. All of these pillars are looking increasingly fragile, and I see nothing that can turn the Russian economy around in the next month.  Brazil does not have the political unity to mount any substantial economic reforms or rescue package. Certainly not by year end. Brazil does have a tendecy to have ping pong growth quarter to quarter which is why I have 4% on option three.

China - Quarterly annualized GDP growth was above 6% last quarter. In the last 10 years, has never dropped by even 4% between quarters, also has never been negative. Plus, even if actual growth rates are dropping off a cliff, very hard to believe the Party would correct this rapidly and suddenly given the last few years (i.e., the reported 'smoothed' data reflects Party decisionmaking). 
India- Same story. Above 7%, no drop of even 4% between Quarters over the last 10 years. 
Russia - Growth was negative last quarter. Question is whether it'll rebound. Russian GDP has risen by more than 5% twice (during the rebound following the great recession). 
Brazil - Similar story as Russia. Only time strong rebound has occurred of more than current rate of shrinkage was twice post crash.  So, I'm at 99-100% for China and India being positive. There's a slight possibility something happens with respect to Russia and Brazil - collectively I'm willing to assign a 2-3% chance that one of them grows. Primarily worried that Russia lies.

It's all down to Russia, I think.  India and China will show positive and Brazil is in full trainwreck. Oil prices are not doing any favours for Russia, and they may be low on cash to give the economy a swift kick; have to check on this.  But of course the opportunities for lying are many and varied.
China and India are undoubtedly in positive annualized growth range;  Russia and Brazil and problematic - Russia because of oil and Brazil because of its historically low growth rate this year.

China and India both consistently show growth, a negative QTR report would have global meltdown implication, no matter the accuracy of the reporting mechanism in the countries. Oil, despite spiking a little today, is well below $45 per barrel needed to increase output and even if there is a spike do to geopolitical events and supply reduction it would be too late to effect Q4. Brazil has surprised in the 4Q before, but would need quite the late rally to over comb economic pitfalls, still not impossible for Brazil, leaving at 10% they can report positive output for Q4.

Further declines in global commodity prices negatively impacts BRC, India won't make same mistakes as Chinese government, push towards services at a time when outsourcing is rapidly growing should drive growth going forward

I'm close to consensus here, with even less range.  This seems to be fairly straight-forward at 2 (China + India) in positive camp and 2 (Brazil + Russia) in negative.  Brazil:  Trend line and forecast are pretty compelling.  It's been getting worse each quarter, and although next q is forecast to slightly improve, getting to positive territory would take a big upside surprise.  Also, Bovespa index has been flat all q, suggesting if something has turned, market has not caught wind of it.  I'm 99/100 it will be a negative.  Russia:  Same story as Brazil.  Here, the move negative was much more abrupt, I think because of oil prices.  I would guess you could have an abrupt move higher as well, but it would take either an oil recovery or a drop in sanctions, neither of which will happen this quarter.  99/100 negative.  (Note: trying to decide on this one if I should be worried that gov't will just fudge / report the wrong number?  It seems like they've been mostly honest in the past regarding gdp, but I got got burned on the S-300 qn and now feel gun-shy...  What if they have some domestic political reason for claiming it's growing again even if it is clear it is not?  We'll see, not factoring this in currently, but will mull it...) India: Easily in yes camp.  Last q was great.  Stock market looks to be down a little in last 3 months, but if q was going to come in negative would have been a much bigger change I think.  Should be positive, 100/100 China:  Also should be easily in yes camp. if you look at historicals and forecast, its not even close.  That said, I have the most indigestion on this one.  There is a TON of news out there that things are not going well in China.  Power output (widely used because many don't trust the gov't numbers) has started to report YoY declines: http://uk.reuters.com/article/china-economy-output-commodities-demand-idUKL3N0RE06320140913.  Manufacturing #'s are slipping each month: http://www.standard.co.uk/business/chinas-economic-woes-continue-as-manufacturing-enters-recession-a3127051.html .  Surrounding mkts are reporting China has pushed them into recessions (Taiwan: http://www.foxbusiness.com/markets/2015/12/01/taiwan-enters-recession-as-china-industrial-sector-is-in-freefall-1162062348/ ; Japan: http://247wallst.com/economy/2015/11/16/japan-slides-into-recession-with-china-to-blame/).  From what I can tell, the picture on the ground is not at all good.  All that said, I REALLY don't think the gov't will report Q4 was negative (even if it was).  In the past they have smoothed as they saw fit (http://www.economist.com/blogs/freeexchange/2015/07/chinese-economy) and would guess probably most likely for that to continue.  Even if they would like to increase the credibility of the official gdp numbers, reporting something negative would be a huge surprise and almost-certainly panic-inducing for mkts, businesses, etc.  Still, leaving a couple %-points on that side of the equation to account for the risk...

Most folks are picking up on India/China vs. Brazil/Russia and I think that's probably a helpful way to look at it. For reference, here are the figures for the last three quarters for each country: Brazil, -2, -3, -4.5 --> http://www.tradingeconomics.com/brazil/gdp-growth-annual
Russia, -2.2, -4.6, -4.1 --> http://www.tradingeconomics.com/russia/gdp-growth-annual
India, 7.5, 7.1, 7.4 --> http://www.tradingeconomics.com/india/gdp-growth-annual
China, 7, 7, 6.9 --> http://www.tradingeconomics.com/china/gdp-growth-annual I think it's safe to say that most folks think China/India will be positive and most folks think that Brazil/Russia will be negative. There's some discussion as to whether Russia can bounce-back and turn a positive number. The key here for me is the price of oil. In using WTI as the barometer, the highest it's been in Q4: 49.63. It's safe to say that WTI has been below 45 for the majority of Q4. We can juxtapose that against Q1 (below 45 only a handful of times) or Q2 (below 45 a handful of times) or Q3 (below 45 for most of August). If we "superimpose" the price of oil on the data above for Russia's growth rate for the last three quarters... I can't see how Russia has a positive Q4. Of course, I'm not certain, and that's why I've left a "2%" chance. ~ This question will be worth revisiting in the last week of December to reassess and make a 'final' forecast before the question closes.

"The Russian economy shrank 4.1 percent year-on-year in the three months to September of 2015,"  http://www.tradingeconomics.com/russia/gdp-growth-annual India:  yes China:  yes I've read that Russia's picture may be improving.  3rd Q wasn't as bad as predicted.  So, I'm allowing for it to possibly be #3.

"None" and "One" implies: either China or India or both have negative growth rates. I think the chance of this is 0.
Two implies that both Russia and Brazil will  be negative, which would be my best guess.
My analysis was incorrect. Looking at it the wrong way.  Ignore this prediction!!  :)

Ok.  I am settled.  Not going to budge unless someone else can provide compelling evidence. India will REALLY have to fudge the numbers even more than they are accused of to exceed 7.5%.   :) Also: Note of caution---When I first saw the question I thought it suggested we have to forecast only a POSTIVE Rgdp number for 2015. TWO was a slam dunk answer!  No..  For the question to close properly we have to forecast the change (postive or negative) BETWEEN 4th qtr 2014 and the 4th quarter 2015.   That changes the way you look at the question. Last years 4th quarters: Brazil +.3   (Brazil in recession. Dont think they will make it)
Russia +.4  (bordering on recession, if not in it.--not sure they can reach this number 4th quarter)
India +7.5%  (????)
China +7.3% (have already downgraded to 6.8% for the 4th qtrI believe)

China positive.
India positive.
Russia negative.
Brazil negative.  Chance of positive?
